content.title: Damage Control Vascular Surgery
content.summary: Staged surgical approach for severely injured patients prioritizing hemorrhage control and physiologic resuscitation over definitive repair, with temporary shunting for vascular injuries.

definitions.definition: Abbreviated surgical intervention focusing on hemorrhage control and contamination limitation, followed by ICU resuscitation, then planned return for definitive repair.
Hypothermia (<35Â°C), acidosis (pH <7.25), and coagulopathy (INR >1.5) - physiologic derangements indicating need for damage control approach.
Prosthetic tube placed within injured artery or vein to restore flow temporarily, allowing physiologic resuscitation before definitive repair.

key_concepts.explanation: Severe physiologic derangement (lethal triad), multiple injuries requiring prolonged surgery, hostile abdomen, transfusion >10 units, inability to obtain definitive hemostasis, or need for additional resources/expertise.

Argyle, Javid, or Pruitt-Inahara shunts are commonly used. Secure with vessel loops or suture. Systemic heparinization if possible but not mandatory. Patency rates >80% at 24-48 hours. Definitive repair within 24-72 hours.

Phase 1: Initial abbreviated surgery (hemorrhage control, shunting, fasciotomy). Phase 2: ICU resuscitation (rewarming, correction of coagulopathy, acidosis). Phase 3: Definitive repair (within 24-72 hours when stable).
Targeting lower blood pressure (SBP 80-90) until hemorrhage control to reduce ongoing blood loss. Not applicable in traumatic brain injury. May reduce transfusion requirements.

evidence.citation: Rotondo et al., Original Damage Control Description, 1993
evidence.finding: Staged approach with abbreviated laparotomy and ICU resuscitation improved survival from 11% to 77% in exsanguinating patients

evidence.citation: Subramanian et al., Temporary Shunt Review, 2008
evidence.finding: Temporary vascular shunts maintain patency >80% when definitive repair is performed within 48 hours

clinical_pearls: Decision for damage control should be made early - don't wait until patient is in extremis
Shunts work best in larger vessels (iliac, femoral, popliteal) - smaller vessels may be ligated
Fasciotomy should be performed prophylactically with prolonged ischemia
Keep shunted patient's legs externally rotated to prevent kinking
Communicate clearly with ICU team regarding resuscitation goals and timing of return
learning_objectives: Identify patients requiring damage control approach
Describe the lethal triad and its implications
Demonstrate temporary vascular shunt insertion technique
Outline the three phases of damage control surgery
State timing for definitive vascular repair after shunting

cross_domain_references.context: Damage control is a general trauma surgery principle applied to vascular injuries
